content.title: Solving Communication-Intensive Problems Efficiently Using On-Chip Mesh Interconnection Networks
content.brief: My Bachelor's thesis about a mesh-connected array processor architecture was presented with a research poster at ISC HPC 2016.
content.abstract: Many mathematical procedures and physical processes are based on highly parallel interaction of information carriers. Traditional concurrent software focuses on adapting established sequential programming models towards increasingly parallel execution. However, communication overhead is still considered a limiting factor, because none of the current processors are really as fast at communicating as they are at computing. Since the late 1970s systolic arrays and other array processors have been developed that exploit the flow of data to implement parallelism, but none of them got engineered to a point where they could be considered general purpose coprocessors. We propose a processor architecture based on a two or three dimensional mesh of processor cores, called the Mesh Processing Unit (MPU). The MPU also represents the first attempt of mapping domain data flow directly to algorithmic topology. The network connecting processors is not a black box, but itâ€˜s the framework for the algorithms that are designed on-top of it. Our work consists of finding a versatile topology for an MPU, simulating program execution by designing a domain specific programing language for it, designing a representative set of algorithms using this language, and evaluating performance of the designed algorithms compared to existing solutions on traditional hardware. The results of our runtime- and utilization benchmarks reveal that MPUs are a capable platform for modern data flow hardware and enable us to invest further research into MPU architecture and algorithm design, as well as the design of a hardware prototype.

content.title: Interactive Colormapping: Enabling Multiple Data Range and Detailed Views of Ocean Salinity
content.brief: CHI 2016 paper about ColorMoves
content.abstract: Ocean salinity is a critical component to understanding climate change. Salinity concentrations and temperature drive large ocean currents which in turn drive global weather patterns. Melting ice caps lower salinity at the poles while river deltas bring fresh water into the ocean worldwide. These processes slow ocean currents, changing weather patterns and producing extreme climate events which disproportionally affect those living in poverty. Analysis of salinity presents a unique visualization challenge. Important data are found in narrow data ranges, varying with global location. Changing values of salinity are important in understanding ocean currents, but are difficult to map to colors using traditional tools. Commonly used colormaps may not provide sufficient detail for this data. Current editing tools do not easily enable a scientist to explore the subtleties of salinity. We present a workflow, enabled by an interactive colormap tool that allows a scientist to interactively apply sophisticated colormaps to scalar data. The intuitive and immediate interaction of the scientist with the data is a critical contribution of this work.

content.title: ColorMoves: Real-time Interactive Colormap Construction for Scientific Visualization
content.brief: CG&A paper about ColorMoves
content.abstract: This article presents ColorMoves, an interactive tool that promotes exploration of scientific data through artist-driven color methods in a unique and transformative way. We discuss the power of contrast in scientific visualization, the design of the ColorMoves tool, and the tools application in several science domains.

content.title: Data Mining Atomically Resolved Images for Material Properties
content.brief: Award winning data challenge project for detecting, classifying and tracking atoms in scanning transmission electron microscopy images
content.abstract: Capturing atomic motion in spectroscopy for observation and quantitatively correlating structure-property relationships with functionality generates insight into physics and chemistry of 2D materials. Feature detection is a widely used technique for extracting atomic motion vectors. We introduce a set of algorithms for tracking motion of molybdenum and selenium atoms, captured throughout a time sequence of scanning transmission electron microscopy images for density functional theory simulations. The discussed set of algorithms efficiently detects, classifies and tracks atoms in the MoSe2 dataset of the 2017 Smokey Mountain Computational Science and Engineering Conference challenge.

content.title: DebugPC
content.brief: An operating system that I wrote from scratch during highschool out of sheer curiosity about how a computer boots.
content.abstract:
Back in technical high school (I majored in machatronics) I asked several computer science and electronics teachers the following question: "How does bootstrap, the process of loading the basic software into the memory of a computer after power-on or general reset [Wikipedia], work?". Unfortunately not a single teach could provide me with a satisfying answer. So I decided to answer it myself
... by programming an operating system!

content.title: Automated Guided Vehicle
content.brief: Together with A.M. PÃ¶llmann, I created an Automated Guided vehicle as final thesis for technical highschool.
content.abstract:
During the last year of our technical high school, I worked with Alexander M. PÃ¶llmann on an Automated Guided Vehicle (AGV) for the in-company transportation of small parts. The prototype was successfully used at EVVA Austria.

The AGV follows preprogrammed routes through the company by following drawn lines on the ground. The lines are detected by a camera system (CMUcam3), which feeds the vehicles Programmable Logic Controller (PLC). The PLC handles navigation through the programmed routes and controlls the two stepper motors that move the vehicle. To avoid collisions with static or moving obstacles, the AGV is equipped with both contact- and contactless sensors.

The thesis consists of the AGV itself (hardware), the software for both PLC (navigation and motor control) and CMUcam3 (visual line and intersection detection), a 3D model of the AGV that won the national CAD competition in 2009 (2009 ARGE 3D-CAD results (German)) and the written thesis.
